title: Nech Sar National Park
subtitle: The White Grass Plains
description: Spanning the narrow isthmus between Lakes Abaya and Chamo, Nech Sar is named for its shimmering pale grasslands that glow silver under the midday sun. The park shelters Swayne's hartebeest, Grant's zebra, and more than 350 bird species within its 514 square kilometres of savannah, groundwater forest, and lakeside terrain.
caption: 06°02′N, 37°35′E — 514 km²

title: The Crocodile Market
subtitle: Lake Chamo’s Living Shoreline
description: At the eastern shore of Lake Chamo, Nile crocodiles—some exceeding six metres—gather in numbers unmatched anywhere else on the continent. Local Gamo fishermen navigate the same waters in papyrus tankwas, an ancient practice that predates written memory. The morning light here is extraordinary.
caption: 05°52′N, 37°34′E — Lake Chamo

title: Dorze Village
subtitle: Weavers of the Highlands
description: Perched at 2,600 metres on the Gughe Mountains, the Dorze people have perfected the art of cotton weaving over centuries. Their towering beehive-shaped houses, built entirely from bamboo and enset leaves, can stand for over 80 years. The village offers a rare window into living traditions untouched by the pace below.
caption: 06°11′N, 37°34′E — 2,600m elevation

title: The Forty Springs
subtitle: Arba Minch’s Namesake
description: The city takes its Amharic name—‘Forty Springs’—from the network of natural springs that bubble up through the dense groundwater forest at the base of the Rift Valley escarpment. Walking the canopy trail above the springs, the air turns cool and heavy with moisture, a stark contrast to the dry plateau above.
caption: 06°02′N, 37°33′E — Groundwater Forest
